III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
Section • (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
Description include all the following:
• (b) The provision of emergency medical, surgical,
and dental care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency has not maintained appropriate communication with
foster family and requests have gone unanswered regarding
medical needs. The agency failed to obtain medical consent timely
causing surgery to be rescheduled for a youth in care.
Investigation Foster Parent was interviewed on 1/7/25 via telephone.
Subsequently to discussing the original allegation, Foster Parent
had the following concerns about Foster Child A, Foster Child B,
and their biological father only. Foster Child A and Foster Child B
are siblings and are placed in the home of Foster Parent.
Foster Child A and Foster Child B are temporary court wards with
the permanency goal of returning home with their biological father.
Foster Child A and Foster Child B’s Biological Mother’s rights
were terminated on 2/10/25. However, Biological Father’s rights
are not terminated, and he is following the treatment plan to
reunite with Foster Child A and Foster Child B.
Foster Parent reported the agency is unresponsive to requests
regarding monitoring Foster Child A and Foster Child B’s medical
needs during their unsupervised visits with Biological Father.
Foster Parent gave the example that when Foster Child A and
Foster Child B returns to her home from the unsupervised visits
with Biological Father, they are constipated. Foster Parent did not
accuse Biological Father of doing anything to cause Foster Child
A and Foster Child B to be constipated. She said this is her
observation when Foster Child A and Foster Child B returns from
the unsupervised visits with Biological Father. Foster Parent
reported Foster Child A is taking a psychotropic medication that
he should take daily. Foster Parent reported she does not believe
Foster Child A’s Biological Father is giving the medication to
Foster Child A when he is having unsupervised visits on the
weekends. Foster Parent did not explain how she knows that
Biological Father is not giving Foster Child A his psychotropic
medication while on his unsupervised overnight visits. This is an
assumption of Foster Parent.
2

Foster Parent reported concerns on Foster Child C, that the
agency failed to obtain medical consent timely causing surgery to
be rescheduled for Foster Child C. She reported Foster Child C
had a medical appointment on 6/27/24 and the doctor reported
Foster Child C to have enlarged tonsils and recommended
Tonsillectomy and Adenoidectomy. She reported the agency has
not obtained surgical consent for Foster Child C in a timely
manner. Foster Parent said Foster Child C’s first scheduled
surgery was cancelled due to the agency failing to gain consent in
time and the surgery had to be rescheduled. The surgery was
scheduled in November of 2024 but was canceled due to not
having surgical consent from Foster Child C’s Biological Mother.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed on 2/27/25 and
3/4/25 via TEAMS and telephone. She reported she discusses
any concerns every Monday with Foster Parent regarding the
unsupervised visits between Foster Child A, Foster Child B with
Biological Father. CA reported Foster Parent suggested that staff
from her agency go to Biological Father’s home on the weekend to
monitor the interactions between Foster Child A, Foster Child B
and Biological Father. CA reported she directed the assigned
Foster Care Worker (FCW) to make a home visit to Biological
Father’s home and monitor the interactions of the unsupervised
visits. FCW went to Biological Father’s home the weekend of
12/21/24 to observe interactions between Foster Child A and
Foster Child B and Biological Father. CA said FCW observed
Foster Child A, Foster Child B and Biological Father engaging in
activities (games) with one another, eating snacks, laughing,
playing together. There was no safety concerns noted. CA
reported FCW did not observe Biological Father give Foster Child
A his medications as the medications are provided to Foster Child
A in the mornings and FCW went to the home in the middle of the
afternoon. CA said FCW reported Biological Father said he did
give Foster Child A his medication that morning when FCW asked
him if he did provide Foster Child A his medication that morning.
CA reported the same information as FCW (noted below)
regarding Foster Child C’s surgery. Foster Child C’s surgery went
well, and he has no complications from the surgery that was
completed on 1/13/25.
3

Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed on 2/27/25 and
3/5/25 via telephone. FCW reported Biological Father is against
administering medication to Foster Child A and Foster Child B and
does not believe in medication, however, FCW said Foster Child A
is on a psychotropic medication and the agency filed a medical
petition against Biological Father and this was granted by the
court judge. Therefore, Biological Father will administer all of
Foster Child A’s medication to him when Foster Child A began his
overnight visits the week of 11/13/24.
FCW reported she provided a medication log to Biological Father
on 12/21/24, to ensure Foster Child A is receiving his medications
during overnight visits. She reported she will review the log
monthly and discuss medications with Biological Father on a
monthly basis. She said she will also ask Foster Child A if he is
taking his medications when he is with Biological Father. FCW did
not observe Biological Father administer the medication to Foster
Child A when she went to the home for a wellbeing check on the
weekend of 12/21/24 but did ask if Biological Father was giving
Foster Child A his medications and he said yes, he was giving
Foster Child A his medications.
FCW reported Foster Child B is currently not on any prescribed
medication. Foster Child B is in the process of getting a full
evaluation for Attention -deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). No
date has been set for this evaluation.
FCW reported Foster Child A and Foster Child B’s immunization
waiver conversation started in early October 2024 with Biological
Father. She said Foster Parent informed the agency on 10/1/24
that the waiver was expiring, and a new one would need to be
obtained. FCW said on 10/3/24, Biological Father informed FCW
he called for an appointment, but the health department was
booked until December of 2024. FCW said the appointment was
set for 12/18/24. Biological Father informed FCW when he called
for the appointment, he was told by the Macomb Health
Department that the waiver was still active, and nothing needed to
be completed right away.
FCW said she called the Macomb Health Department on 12/20/24
and was informed that biological father did not attend the
scheduled appointment. She said she called biological father on
12/30/24 about what she had learned and gave him until the end
of the day on 12/30/24 to obtain a new date for the appointment.
On 12/30/24 Biological Father called FCW and stated he spoke
with the Macomb Health Department on 12/18/24 and the worker
4

there said the current waiver was active and to call back after the
New Year.
FCW said Biological Father called FCW on 1/2/25, to ask
questions regarding the waiver. FCW said she informed Biological
Father on 1/2/25, that the waiver was not completed properly.
FCW said Biological Father was directed by Macomb County
Health Department to go to Wayne County Health Department to
get the waiver rectified. FCW said Biological Father called her and
informed her that he would be going to the Wayne County Health
Department before 3pm on 1/3/25. FCW said on 1/6/25, she
asked Biological Father for a copy of the waiver. She said he sent
the waiver to her on 1/6/25, and the document was dated 1/3/25.
FCW said she forwarded the waiver to Foster Parent on 1/6/25.
FCW reported Foster Child C became a permanent ward on
2/10/25, and Foster Parent was able to obtain Foster Child C’s
orders for medications and parent consent which makes things
easier for her in dealing with Foster Child C’s medical issues.
FCW explained Foster Child C’s surgery was delayed because the
agency had to obtain surgical consent from Biological Mother and
during that time when Foster Parent discussed the
recommendation from the doctor on 6/27/24, Biological Mother
was not available and could not be found as she was MIA. FCW
reported Biological Mother would not respond to text messages or
telephone calls. She reported Biological Mother’s last
communication was in April 2024 when she stated it was not in the
best interest of Foster Child A, Foster Child B or Foster Child C to
see her.
FCW reported when Foster Child C was taken to the doctor and
the doctor recommended Foster Child C needed his tonsil and
adenoids remove on 6/27/24, the doctor was unaware that Foster
Child C was in foster care and Foster Parent was not his biological
mother. Therefore, surgical consent had to be obtained by Foster
Child C’s Biological Mother. FCW reported her rights were not
terminated during this time and Biological Mother had to be
located to obtain the consent and this took some time. When she
was located in January 2025, she wanted additional information to
make sure this surgery was necessary. FCW said Biological
Mother signed the consent paperwork in January 2025. FCW said
when the doctor received Foster Child C’s paperwork in January
2025, it took some time for the doctor to schedule an appointment
for the surgery for Foster Child C which made for additional
delays. She said it was explained to Foster Parent that these
matters do take time. FCW said paperwork was submitted to the
5

doctor 1/8/25 and the surgery was scheduled for 1/13/25. FCW
explained this surgery was not routine nor an emergency but a
planned procedure therefore, the consent had to come from
Biological Mother. Part of the delay of getting the surgery
scheduled was discussing the surgery with the doctor’s surgery
coordinator and finding a time for Foster Child C’s surgery to take
place and/or be scheduled.
FCW reported that Foster Child C’s surgery went well, and he has
no complications from the surgery that was completed on 1/13/25.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed on 3/4/25 via
TEAMS. FCS provided some history of the siblings placed in
Foster Parent’s home. She reported Foster Parent has three
children placed in her home, Foster Child A, Foster Child B and
Foster Child C, who are siblings with the same mother and
different fathers. She reported similar information as CA and
FCW. She added that Foster Parent is not on board with the
permanency plan of Foster Child A and Foster Child B.
She reported she talks with Foster Parent daily about anything
she wants to discuss regarding medical needs, behaviors and
Biological Father. FCS reports Foster Parent is not happy about
the possibility of Foster Child A, Foster Child B returning home
with Biological Father. She said Foster Child C’s parental rights
from Biological Mother was terminated on 2/10/25 and Foster
Child C’s father’s rights were terminated on 2/10/25. FCS
reported Foster Child C is in the process of being adopted by
Foster Parent and that Foster Parent would like to keep Foster
Child A, Foster Child B and Foster Child C together and in her
home as she has really bonded with the siblings, and she enjoys
having them in her home.
FCS reported the same information as FCW regarding Foster
Child C’s surgery. Foster Child C’s surgery went well, and he has
no complications from the surgery that was completed on 1/13/25.
Documents reviewed:
• Foster Child A, Foster Child B and Foster Child C’s Case
records were reviewed:
• Foster Child A is prescribed the psychotropic medication
dexmethylphenidate, albuterol and cetirizine.
• Foster Child B is not taking any medication; however, he is
in the process of being scheduled for a full evaluation for
attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
6

• Foster Child C is prescribed four psychotropic medications.
clonidine, oxcarbazepine, methylphenidates and
atomoxetine. The three siblings were placed in the home
of the Foster Parent from 6/13/17 – 3/4/20. They returned
to bio mother from 3/4/20 – 6/2/20 then returned back to
Foster Parent from 9/22/21 to present.
• Updated services plan dated 1/9/24 – 4/5/24 recommended
that Foster Child A and Foster Child B remain Temporary
Court wards in their current placement with the
permanency goal of reunification with their biological father.
Visitation began in the biological father’s home on 4/6/24.
• Agency policy on medical, surgical and dental care states,
all children in care who are in need of emergency medical
and surgical care, a written consent is to be obtained from
the legal guardian and/or parent.
• Court report dated 11/13/24, states biological father is
offered weekly unsupervised overnight visits on Saturday
and Sunday’s and family therapy bi-weekly on Thursdays
for his sons, Foster Child A and Foster Child B. Bio
mother’s rights are terminated for all three brothers, Foster
Child A, Foster Child B and Foster Child C.
• Documentation was reviewed and confirmed the
medication log, (Photos) that is sent to the FCW monthly
from Biological Father for review regarding administering
medications to Foster Child A during unsupervised visits.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted with the agency staff, there were
some delays with getting an immunization wavier timely as well as
scheduling a surgical procedure for Foster Child C. However, the
agency staff had to work with other agencies, the agencies system
as well as locate the biological mother of Foster Child C to get her
consent for Foster Child C’s surgery to schedule the surgical
procedure. These steps were time consuming, and the agency
appeared to be working and communicating with Foster Parent
daily. Immunization waivers and surgical procedure presented in
October of 2024 were resolved. The medical procedure of Foster
Child C was completed in January of 2025.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
